also don’t know whether that initial state favored certain sorts of molecular
changes rather than others. We have reason to think that Behe’s assumption
that there’s a precise chance of 1 in 30,000 that each gene piece will participate
in the “shuffling” process is incorrect. For, given what we know about mecha-
nisms within the genome, the idea of exactly equal chances is suspect. But we
